what: Challenges in Biological Gene Enrichment Analysis
title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: Gene enrichment analysis can often misleading due redundancy within gene set databases limitations enrichment tools. Many tools, default, display top results fail filter redundancy. can result biological misinterpretation valuable information overlooked. instance, high expression certain immune genes can cause many immune-related gene sets appear overrepresented. However, closer look often reveals gene sets derived group genes, might represent small fraction (less 10%) differentially expressed genes (DEGs). 90%? hold biological significance?

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: EnrichGT based clusterProfiler. clusterProfiler one powerful tools R enrichment analysis. ’s designed pathway redundancy mind includes clusterProfiler::simplify function address issue. method, based GOSemSim GO similarity evaluation, scientifically robust highly effective. However, drawbacks: GOSemSim fast, particularly dealing large complex gene sets. doesn’t support databases like KEGG Reactome. Using GOSemSim measure semantic similarity pathways , theoretically, best way tackle redundancy. However, practical cases—especially experimental bioinformatics validation—researchers focused genes behind pathways rather pathways .

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: Although clustering pathways based gene overlap received criticism, remains viable approach many situations. reason, developed BioThemeFinder years ago solve problem. However, tool awful (poor coding…) Today, two excellent alternatives exist: simplifyEnrichment: package scientifically rigorous (based semantic similarity) creates beautiful visualizations. aPEAR: simpler faster tool better aligns practical needs, making preferred choice. However, tools common limitation: visualizations optimized publication purposes rather exploratory research. often find exporting CSV files struggling RStudio’s preview pane fully explore enrichment tables. inspired develop efficient solution.

title: Parse and cluster biological enrichment result to great tables
text: main purpose developing package provide lightweight practical solution problems mentioned . Specifically, package aims : Cluster enrichment results based hit genes core enrichment GSEA using term frequency analysis (output powerful clusterProfiler. provides clearer view biological relevance focusing genes matter . Visualize results using Posit PBC gt package, offers two key advantages: Improved readability compared traditional tables, making easier interpret results. HTML-based output allows internal searching filtering, making exploration user-friendly. Seamless Integration Publishing Tools : Another significant advantage using gt package seamless integration modern publishing systems like Rmarkdown quarto. ensures results can easily shared published professional format, also allowing interactive exploration research phase. ’re tired redundant pathways cluttering enrichment results spending much time computational bottlenecks, package help.

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: x enrichment result `clusterProfiler`, `data.frame` containing result `clusterProfier` ClusterNum many cluster clustered P.adj p.adjust cut-. avoid slow visualization, can make stricter p-cut . force ignore auto-self-checks, useful nTop keep n top items according p-adj cluster. ... Others options.

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: `EnrichGT_obj` object. slot `enriched_result` contains data.frame enriched results. `gt_object` contains `gt` object. can use `obj@gt_object` get use functions `gt` like `gtsave`. `gene_modules` list containing meta-gene modules cluster. `pathway_clusters` contains pathways names cluster.

title: Parse enrichment results and further clustering and visualizing — EnrichGT
text: ORA result, c("ID","Description","GeneRatio","pvalue","p.adjust","geneID","Count") contained; GSEA, c("ID","Description","NES","pvalue","p.adjust","core_enrichment") contain. `compareClusterResult`, `compareClusterResult` object data-frame additional `Cluster` column contained, others similar ORA result.
